page_title: Liquid Embolic Device Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
hero_description: Liquid embolic agents face unique validation challenges requiring polymer viscosity measurement, radiopacity verification, and polymerization timing control that standard biocompatibility testing cannot address. We test DMSO compatibility, tantalum suspension stability, controlled precipitation behavior, and tissue uptake patterns across aneurysm, AVM, and peripheral embolization applications for both 510(k) and PMA submissions.
primary_content_description: Liquid embolic agents must solidify at precisely the right speed during deployment. Too fast and the polymer blocks your delivery catheter. Too slow and it flows beyond the target vessel before hardening. We test how viscosity changes during injection, measure polymerization timing under different conditions, and verify that tantalum particles stay suspended throughout the procedure so your device remains visible under fluoroscopy. We track polymer behavior using real-time imaging that captures precipitation patterns as liquid transitions to solid. DMSO compatibility testing ensures your carrier solvent doesn't damage microcatheters during extended procedures. Advanced tissue analysis measures how deeply the polymer penetrates vessel walls and surrounding tissue. Our protocols evaluate coating uniformity, radiopacity across different thicknesses, and complete occlusion effectiveness in anatomically accurate aneurysm models. ISO 10993 biocompatibility standards guide material evaluation while device-specific protocols address DMSO toxicity, polymer degradation, and tissue response at embolization sites. Our testing supports both 510(k) pathways for devices similar to established embolics and PMA submissions for novel formulations. Whether validating polymer viscosity for aneurysm treatment or characterizing precipitation control for AVM applications, our catheterization laboratories provide the imaging and measurement capabilities liquid embolic validation requires.
capability_1_description: We measure how easily your liquid embolic flows through microcatheters at different temperatures and injection speeds, tracking viscosity changes that affect delivery control and occlusion success.
capability_2_description: Real-time imaging captures how fast your polymer solidifies after contacting blood or tissue, measuring precipitation rates that determine whether the embolic stays where you place it.
capability_3_description: Fluoroscopic testing verifies that tantalum or other radiopaque markers provide clear visualization during injection and follow-up, measuring visibility across different polymer thicknesses and vessel sizes.
capability_4_description: Specialized protocols test whether DMSO damages microcatheter materials during extended procedures while evaluating tissue toxicity and vascular response to the carrier solvent.
capability_5_description: Histological analysis measures how deeply polymer penetrates aneurysm walls and surrounding tissue, mapping distribution patterns that predict occlusion completeness and durability.
capability_6_description: Anatomically accurate models test complete vessel sealing across aneurysm, AVM, and peripheral applications, measuring immediate occlusion success and long-term stability under pulsatile flow.
why_choose_title: Why Choose Synchrony for Liquid Embolic Testing
why_choose_1_description: Our catheterization laboratories feature fluoroscopy systems configured specifically for liquid embolic visualization with high frame rates that capture rapid precipitation events. Advanced imaging tracks polymer flow in real-time while specialized protocols measure radiopacity across varying concentrations and thicknesses. This infrastructure enables comprehensive liquid embolic testing that standard vascular labs cannot provide.
why_choose_2_description: Our team combines neurovascular intervention experience with polymer science knowledge specific to embolic applications. We understand how DMSO interacts with catheter materials, how precipitation timing affects occlusion success, and which polymerization patterns predict clinical performance. This expertise translates to testing protocols that address both material science challenges and neurovascular safety requirements for liquid embolic devices.
why_choose_3_description: Our data packages have supported FDA submissions for embolic devices across aneurysm, AVM, and peripheral applications. We understand how to demonstrate DMSO safety, characterize polymer biocompatibility, and validate occlusion effectiveness through testing protocols FDA expects. Whether pursuing 510(k) clearance or PMA approval for novel formulations, our testing addresses regulatory requirements specific to liquid embolic combination products.
cta_description: Our team is ready to discuss your liquid embolic device, regulatory pathway, and study requirements to optimize your path to FDA approval.

page_title: Thrombectomy Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
hero_description: Successful thrombectomy requires devices that grab clots effectively, retrieve them without vessel damage, and achieve complete recanalization on the first attempt. We test stent retriever deployment mechanics, aspiration force generation, clot extraction efficiency, and first-pass success rates across stroke, MI, and peripheral thrombosis applications for both 510(k) and PMA submissions.
primary_content_description: Thrombectomy devices must grab clots effectively without tearing blood vessels during retrieval. Stent retrievers need to expand precisely to engage thrombus while maintaining vessel wall contact. Aspiration catheters must generate enough suction to pull clots out without fragmenting them. We test how devices perform across fresh platelet-rich clots and older organized thrombi because different clot types require different removal forces and techniques. Our protocols measure clot engagement success using force sensors that track how well devices capture thrombus during deployment. High-speed imaging documents retrieval mechanics while tracking whether clots break apart and send fragments downstream. We evaluate vessel preservation by measuring endothelial damage after multiple retrieval attempts. Anatomically accurate stroke models replicate cerebral vessel tortuosity while pulsatile flow systems simulate physiological conditions during emergency procedures. ISO 10993 biocompatibility standards guide material safety evaluation while thrombectomy-specific protocols assess rapid deployment requirements and emergency use scenarios. Our testing supports 510(k) pathways for devices similar to cleared retrievers and PMA submissions for novel clot removal mechanisms. Whether validating stent retriever expansion for stroke intervention or measuring aspiration efficiency for coronary thrombectomy, our neurovascular laboratories provide the imaging capabilities and clot models mechanical thrombectomy validation requires.
capability_1_description: We measure how much force devices need to capture and remove different clot types, tracking engagement success rates and retrieval mechanics that predict clinical performance across stroke and thrombosis scenarios.
capability_2_description: Testing protocols evaluate complete clot removal on the first retrieval attempt using TICI scoring systems, measuring the critical performance metric that correlates with patient outcomes in stroke intervention.
capability_3_description: Specialized protocols assess endothelial damage after retrieval attempts, measuring vessel trauma that could cause perforation or dissection during emergency thrombectomy procedures in delicate cerebral vessels.
capability_4_description: High-speed imaging captures clot fragmentation during retrieval while sensitive particle detection measures embolic debris release, quantifying the safety risk of sending clot fragments to downstream vessels.
capability_5_description: For stent-based devices, we test radial force generation, vessel apposition quality, and clot integration patterns using fluoroscopy that documents deployment precision in tortuous neurovascular anatomy.
capability_6_description: Aspiration catheter testing measures vacuum generation, flow rates through different catheter sizes, and extraction efficiency across varying clot compositions to optimize suction-based thrombectomy effectiveness.
why_choose_title: Why Choose Synchrony for Thrombectomy Testing
why_choose_1_description: Our catheterization labs feature anatomically accurate cerebral vessel models that replicate the tortuosity and branching patterns encountered during stroke intervention. High-frame-rate fluoroscopy captures rapid retrieval events while force measurement systems quantify clot engagement mechanics in real-time. This specialized infrastructure enables thrombectomy testing that simulates emergency stroke procedures with the precision regulatory submissions require.
why_choose_2_description: We prepare standardized clot analogs that match the mechanical properties of actual stroke, MI, and peripheral thrombi including fresh platelet-rich clots and organized fibrin material. Our team understands how clot age and composition affect retrieval difficulty, creating test conditions that predict clinical performance. This expertise ensures your device faces realistic challenges that demonstrate effectiveness across the spectrum of thrombotic occlusions physicians encounter.
why_choose_3_description: Our testing has supported FDA submissions for stent retrievers, aspiration catheters, and combination thrombectomy devices across neurovascular and coronary applications. We understand how to demonstrate first-pass success, characterize vessel safety, and validate performance through protocols FDA expects for time-critical emergency devices. Whether pursuing 510(k) clearance or breakthrough device designation for novel mechanisms, our data addresses thrombectomy-specific regulatory requirements.
cta_description: Our team is ready to discuss your thrombectomy device, clot removal mechanism, and regulatory pathway to accelerate your path to clinical use.

page_title: Direct Aspiration Thrombectomy Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
hero_description: Aspiration thrombectomy success depends on generating sufficient vacuum force, maintaining catheter trackability through tortuous vessels, and extracting clots without fragmentation. We test suction pressure generation, catheter navigation performance, clot extraction efficiency across fresh and organized thrombi, and complete recanalization achievement for stroke, coronary, and peripheral applications supporting both 510(k) and PMA pathways.
primary_content_description: Direct aspiration catheters must generate enough suction to pull clots from occluded vessels while staying flexible enough to navigate tortuous anatomy. Too much vacuum and the catheter collapses inward. Too little and clots won't budge. We measure how much negative pressure your catheter generates at different flow rates and track whether that suction stays consistent during extended procedures across varying catheter diameters and lengths. Our protocols test extraction success across different clot types because fresh platelet-rich thrombi extract differently than organized fibrin material. Force measurement systems track how much suction each clot composition requires while high-speed imaging documents whether clots come out intact or fragment during aspiration. We evaluate catheter deliverability through anatomically accurate stroke models that replicate cerebral vessel tortuosity. Pulsatile flow systems simulate physiological conditions that affect vacuum transmission from pump to catheter tip. ISO 10993 biocompatibility standards guide blood contact evaluation while aspiration-specific protocols assess vacuum effects on vessel walls and hemolysis potential. Our testing supports 510(k) pathways for devices similar to cleared aspiration catheters and PMA submissions for novel vacuum generation systems or catheter designs. Whether validating suction performance for neurovascular stroke or measuring extraction efficiency for coronary MI, our catheterization laboratories provide the pressure measurement capabilities and clot models direct aspiration validation requires.
capability_1_description: We measure peak suction pressure and sustained vacuum maintenance across different catheter configurations, tracking how negative pressure changes with catheter length, diameter, and aspiration system type during simulated procedures.
capability_2_description: Protocols evaluate complete clot removal rates across fresh and organized thrombi using standardized clot analogs, measuring extraction success and identifying which clot characteristics affect aspiration performance.
capability_3_description: Anatomically accurate models test how easily catheters navigate through tortuous neurovascular and coronary anatomy, measuring push force requirements and tip deflection during advancement to target vessels.
capability_4_description: High-speed imaging captures whether clots break apart during aspiration while particle detection measures embolic debris generation, quantifying the risk of sending fragments to downstream vessels during extraction.
capability_5_description: Testing measures fluid flow rates through different catheter sizes under varying vacuum levels, characterizing aspiration dynamics that determine how quickly and effectively devices remove occlusive material from vessels.
capability_6_description: Specialized blood contact testing evaluates red blood cell damage from aspiration forces while thrombogenicity protocols assess clot formation risk on catheter surfaces during extended vacuum exposure to flowing blood.
why_choose_title: Why Choose Synchrony for Direct Aspiration Testing
why_choose_1_description: Our catheterization labs feature calibrated pressure transducers that measure vacuum generation at the catheter tip rather than just at the pump, capturing the actual suction force available for clot extraction. Real-time pressure monitoring tracks how vacuum changes during simulated procedures while flow sensors measure aspiration dynamics through different catheter configurations. This precision measurement infrastructure provides the quantitative aspiration data regulatory submissions require.
why_choose_2_description: We test aspiration catheters across neurovascular stroke, coronary MI, and peripheral thrombosis applications using appropriate vessel models and clot types for each territory. Our team understands how aspiration requirements differ between cerebral arteries, coronary vessels, and peripheral circulation. This cross-specialty expertise ensures your device faces testing conditions that match intended clinical use whether targeting stroke, heart attack, or limb ischemia treatment.
why_choose_3_description: Our testing has supported FDA submissions for direct aspiration catheters, vacuum generation systems, and combination aspiration devices across multiple vascular territories. We understand how to demonstrate suction effectiveness, characterize clot extraction efficiency, and validate safety through protocols FDA expects for aspiration thrombectomy devices. Whether pursuing 510(k) clearance through predicate comparison or PMA approval for novel aspiration mechanisms, our data addresses aspiration-specific regulatory requirements.
cta_description: Our team is ready to discuss your aspiration catheter design, vacuum generation system, and testing protocol to validate your device performance.
